Award.AwardTitle: Seeking Hidden Glaciations of the Greenhouse World
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Eocene Epoch (56 to 34 million years ago) is generally thought of as a period of "greenhouse" climate conditions, but some evidence suggests that brief episodes of Antarctic glaciation may have occurred during this time. However, evidence for such glacial periods is indirect and up to now has not been firmly substantiated or characterized. This leaves significant gaps in our understanding of Eocene climate behavior, and of the processes associated with a period of profound change in Earth's history.

The proposed work, led by a scientist from the University of South Carolina, will address this knowledge gap by using neodymium (Nd) and strontium (Sr) isotopic records to determine the timing, extent, and frequency of Eocene glacial events. Glacial weathering of Antarctic rocks produces detrital sediment with a unique isotopic signature, meaning that sediment produced on the Antarctic continent and deposited on the seafloor during glaciation is distinguishable within sediment cores. The project is motivated by preliminary Nd data that indicate a significant episode of Eocene glaciation ca. 37 million years ago, 3 million years earlier than previous estimates of the earliest Antarctic glaciation. To further identify and constrain glacial events in the middle to late Eocene, the proposed work will generate Nd and Sr records from Southern Ocean sediment cores collected by the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP).

The datasets produced by this project will be relevant not only to understanding past Antarctic glaciation, but also to constraining low-latitude nutrient dynamics and productivity (for which glacial weathering is an important parameter). In this way, the proposed work aligns closely with the objectives of the Pacific Equatorial Age Transect (PEAT), a science program implemented by IODP. The project will involve an undergraduate and a graduate student. The project leader will also work with educators to develop Earth Science literacy programs for elementary school children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid industrial and technological expansion since 1850 required the combustion of fossil fuels, coal, oil, and natural gas. One of the products of fossil fuel combustion is carbon dioxide (CO2), which is released into the atmosphere where it contributes to the Earth’s greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect is a natural process and is one of the factors that make Earth a habitable planet. The rate of CO2 release due to burning fossil fuels has increased CO2 levels from 280 parts per million (ppm) at the end of the pre-industrial period to 400 ppm today. If fossil fuel burning continues into the future at comparable rates to the past 150 years CO2 levels are projected to reach 1000 ppm. The last time CO2 levels were this high was 35 million years ago, during a geological epoch called the Eocene.

 

The Eocene was a very different world from today. For many years, scientists studying the climate of the Eocene believed the world was largely ice-free. However over the last 10 years there has been evidence presented for rapid and large changes in sea level during the Eocene, pointing to growth and decay of ice sheets. There have also been reports of Eocene sediments in polar seas that could have been derived by glacial weathering. Considering how important ice sheets are to our current climate state, and the fact that CO2 will reach Eocene levels in this century, the question of whether ice sheets existed at the poles is timely and scientifically interesting.

 

With the support from this award we examined the Eocene sedimentary record around Antarctica and found substantial variations in the source of weathered an eroded material coming of off Antarctica during the transition between the middle and late Eocene, approximately 37.3 million years ago. Combined with evidence for ocean cooling these results indicate that a small-to-medium size ice sheet formed on Antarctica during this time. This glaciation has now been recognized at three different locations, and is coincident with a 10-20 m sea level drop and general climate cooling. We have named this event the Priabonian Oxygen isotope Maximum or PROM, which is now recognized as an important step in the evolution of global climate.

 

This project supported development of a early career scientist and fostered collaboration between two early career scientists, two M.S. students, and several undergraduate research assistants.
